comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Douglas A4D-1 Skyhawk 139925 VX-5 ‘Vampires’ code XE side number 7 Seen carrying a T-63 tactical nuclear weapon shape on its center line pylon without retractable lower stabilizing fin. At that time the role of VX-5 was testing and devising methods of nuclear weapons delivery. The T-63/T63 was a test shape for the Mark 7 tactical nuclear implosion bomb. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_7_nuclear_bomb A4D-1 139925 was accepted by the US Navy on August 23 1956 and went straight to VX-5 on August 25, 1956 as a weapons test platform. Then spent four years with various training and support units from California based Navy air stations until 1963, when stored at the NAF Litchfield Park Arizona desert compound. After November 1962 all US Navy aircraft designations were simplified, and A4D-1 became A-4A. USAF & USN storage was combined into one organization in 1965 and A4D-1 139925 was moved on to MASDC near Tucson. Returned to service in 1966 as a Reserve trainer from bases in California and Kansas it flew until 1969 when Struck Off Charge. The above image may also be viewed in this viewable/downloadable PDF document on pages 80-81 www.scribd.com/doc/78713120/Naval-Fighters-49-Douglas-A-4... Caption reads; “A4D-1 139925 carries another T-63. Tail and fuselage stripes were dark green bordered by white. The nose of the aircraft and the T-63 were da-glo red.” Period picture of A4D-1 139925 with VX-5: a4skyhawk.org/content/buno-139925-vx-5-xe-7 A4D-1 139925 VX-5 code XE side number 7 Photo Credit: C. Gilbert VX-5 A4D-1 Skyhawk BuNo 139925, XE-7, special weapons, next to VA-54 AD-7 Skyraider BuNo 142070, Armitage Field, circa 1957 Low resolution scan of period picture with A4D-1 139925 of VX-5: a4skyhawk.org/content/139925-vx-5-official-us-navy-photo-144 A4D-1 139925 VX-5 code XE side number 7 circa 1957 Photo Credit: official U.S. Navy photo right side air to air view of Vampires Skyhawk BuNo 139925, XE-7, with a centerline mounted special test shape (All information and images courtesy the ‘A-4 Skyhawk Association’)
